>   assertTrue( rainbow.contains( Color.orange ) );
> 
> If it fails, I have three choices for figuring out what rainbow contains so
> I can start figuring out where orange went:
> 
> 1. Put the color list into the assert message:
> 2. Put in a debugging string (BTW, this is what I thought the OP meant when
> he said "logging", but of course I was wrong):
> 
>   System.out.println( "Rainbow: " + rainbow.colorListAsString() );
>   assertTrue( rainbow.contains( Color.orange ) );

Comment for the 2nd option:

The problem is that when you have debugged your code, you will delete your
System.out.println statement.  And chances are that sooner or later you will
face the same problem somewhere else.  So you'll have to write your System.out
statement, debug the code and delete the statement.

How I work is a mix between 1) and 2): I write my custom assert class.  In this
case, I would write a class:

   class ListAssert {
      public static void assertContains(List actual, Object expected) {
         if (!actual.contains(expected)) {
            /* construct a message that precisely describes what happened
             * and all the values contained in the List, so that it's
             * easy to debug */
            String msg = ...;
            fail(msg);
         }
      }
   }

You don't have to change all your "assertTrue(...contains(...))" assertions in
all of your JUnit tests, but simply once one of these tests fails, replace the
assertTrue by your custom assertion, recompile and reexecute the tests.

And once the assertion is in your test code, it stays there (not like a
System.out call).

And once you have written this class, you can send it to me and I'll include it
into the JUnit-addons library.

-Vladimir
